values.text: COVID-19 affects different people in different ways. Most infected people will develop mild to moderate illness and recover without hospitalization. The symptoms can range as follows :
Most common symptoms: fever, dry cough, cold and tiredness
Less common symptoms: aches and pains, sore throat, diarrhoea, conjunctivitis, headache, loss of taste or smell, a rash on skin, or discolouration of fingers or toes

Serious symptoms: difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, chest pain or pressure, loss of speech or movement. Seek immediate medical attention if you have serious symptoms. Always call before visiting your doctor or health facility.

values: Try again later.

values.text: $webhook_result_1.result

High diabetes especially uncontrolled can be a problem, if you are a patient of that category then stay at home unless going out is absolutely necessary, if you need to consult a doctor then do it on phone or video call.

Having cancer currently increases your risk of severe illness from COVID-19. At this time, it is not known whether having a history of cancer increases your risk. If you have previous history of cancer then try staying at home and taking all the necessary precautions. You can do the following things :

(1) Have a conversation with your healthcare provider or care team to discuss your individual level of risk based on your condition, your treatment, and the level of transmission in your community. Try doing this on phone or video call.
(2) Do not stop taking your medicines or alter your treatment plan without talking to your healthcare provider.
(3) Make sure that you have at least a 30-day supply of your medicines and do not delay life-saving treatment or emergency care.

Don't worry, stay calm. People with certain medical conditions can be at risk and that's why practising common sense of prevention is critical during this outbreak crisis. Avoid risk exposure, wash hand, wear mask as needed. Follow all the CDC guidelines for being safe. Effective drugs are under development.

You can refer to these CDC guidelines if you have a serious medical condition and are at high risk : https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/people-with-medical-conditions.html
Follow these CDC guidelines on keeping yourself safe : https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/prevent-getting-sick/prevention.html

As pregnant women are at a high risk it is advised that you do not skip your prenatal care appointments and limit your interactions with other people as much as possible. If you do interact, take precautions. Make sure that you have at least a 30-day supply of your medicines. It is important you talk to your healthcare provider about how to stay healthy and take care of yourself during the COVID-19 pandemic. In case you do not have one, contact your nearest community health or health department. Seek care immediately in terms of any medical emergency.
You can also refer to these guidelines provided by CDC : https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/pregnancy-breastfeeding.html

Quarantine is used to keep someone who might have been exposed to COVID-19 away from others. It helps prevent spread of disease that can occur before a person knows they are sick or if they are infected with the virus without feeling symptoms. People in quarantine should stay home, separate themselves from others, monitor their health, and follow directions from their state or local health department.
If you need more information on home quarantine, these are a few guidelines provided by the World Health Organization (WHO) : https://www.mohfw.gov.in/pdf/Guidelinesforhomequarantine.pdf
I know about Covid-19.
I'm specialising in Covid-19 so I can respond to all your queries.
I have all the information about Covid-19. And even if I don't I'm always trying to learn more and more about it!
I'm CoviBro. I'm a bot designed to help you with all your Covid-19 queries.
Hello I'm CoviBro! I am a bot designed to help you get through this pandemic.
I am CoviBro. I'm here to help you get information regarding Covid-19.
Hi, I'm CoviBro! I am a bot designed to answer your questions about Covid-19.
Hello. I'm CoviBro, a Covid-19 bot that's here to help you get through this pandemic. I can give you information about this virus.
I'm CoviBro! I am a bot made to help the humans confused about what Covid-19 is.
I'm CoviBro. I'm the bot you need for all your Covid queries!
Employees who develop symptoms outside of work should notify their supervisor and stay home.
Employees who have symptoms when they arrive at work or become sick during the day should immediately be separated from other employees, customers, and visitors and sent home.
Need help with what to do if an employee shows symptoms or is tested positive?

In most cases, you do not need to shut down your facility. But do close off any areas used for prolonged periods of time by the sick person. Wait 24 hours before cleaning and disinfecting to minimize potential for other employees being exposed to respiratory droplets.
If the employee is tested positive and has used the facility less than 7 days ago, clean and disinfect all areas used by the sick employee following the CDC cleaning and disinfection recommendations.

Okay.
I understand this is all too new but this is exactly what I was designed for. You can ask me about anything related to Covid-19, I'll do my best to give you the necessary information.
It is natural to be confused and lost, specially because a lot is still yet to be discovered about the coronavirus. But I'm here to give you all the information I can.
I understand you're lost and confused. But don't worry, ask me anything about Covid-19 and I'll try helping you by providing the necessary information.

Staying at home can be quite nice for some time, but can also be boring and restricting.
Here are some ways to keep positive and cheerful.
Be busy. Have a regular schedule. Help in doing some of the work at home.

Distract yourself from negative emotions by listening to music, reading, watching an
entertaining programme on television. If you had old hobbies like painting, gardening or
stitching, go back to them. Rediscover your hobbies.

Knowledge is power; the more you know about a certain issue, the less fearful you may
feel. Make sure to access and believe only the most reliable sources of information for
self-protection.

It's normal to be overwhelmed and confused during a pandemic, you need to be kind to yourself. Don't beat yourself up and take a break when necessary. You can always pick new hobbies and try new things to get your mind off negative thoughts.

Breathe in... Breathe out.. Take a moment for yourself. It is natural to be overwhelmed with emotions in a time like this. Take some time off, talk to your loved ones. If you need help with information regarding Covid-19 you can always ask me for it!
Don't worry! I understand it's a very difficult and confusing time, but we're all in this fight together. If you need any information about the virus you can always ask me. I'm here for you.

Relax... At times of anxiety, practice breathing slowly for a few minutes. Try and distance the
thoughts that are making you anxious. Think of something calm and serene, and slow
down your mind.
I know this is a difficult time and it's hard to predict when will the pandemic end, but I'm positive it will all be better soon.
I know it seems like this crisis will never come to and end, but everything will be okay. Be positive and do your part of preventing the virus from spreading.

It is a difficult time because no one can accurately predict the end of the virus, but we're all in this together. Together we can take the necessary care and precautions and can stop the virus from spreading further.

values.text: I don't seem to have that.
If you show symptoms of the Covid 19 or have come in contact with someone who has been tested positive, it is advised to get yourself tested too.

Two kinds of tests are available for COVID-19: viral tests and antibody tests.
A viral test tells you if you have a current infection.
An antibody test might tell you if you had a past infection. An antibody test might not show if you have a current infection because it can take 1–3 weeks after infection for your body to make antibodies.

To learn if you have a current infection, viral tests are used. Most people have mild illness and can recover at home without medical care. Contact your healthcare provider if your symptoms are getting worse or if you have questions about your health.​​
You can always visit your state or local health department’s website to look for the latest local information on testing.
If you have mild symptoms and choose to stay at home, see the following guidelines provided by WHO : https://www.mohfw.gov.in/pdf/Guidelinesforhomequarantine.pdf

values: I'm here for you! What do you need?
I'm here for all your Covid 19 related queries! Ask away.
CoviBro reporting on duty. What do you need?

Coronavirus Disease 2019 (Covid 19) is an illness caused by a novel coronavirus that causes respiratory symptoms along with fever and cough. A diagnosis with COVID-19 will be evaluated and cared for differently as the virus can spread at rapid rates causing massive outbreaks.

values.text: Quarantine means separating a person or group of people who have been exposed to a contagious disease but have not developed illness (symptoms) from others who have not been exposed, in order to prevent the possible spread of that disease. Quarantine is usually established for the incubation period of the communicable disease, which is the span of time during which people have developed illness after exposure.

For COVID-19, the period of quarantine is 14 days from the last date of exposure, because 14 days is the longest incubation period seen for similar coronaviruses. Someone who has been released from COVID-19 quarantine is not considered a risk for spreading the virus to others because they have not developed illness during the incubation period.
If you want more help regarding home quarantine, you can see the following guidelines provided by the World Health Organisation (WHO) : https://www.mohfw.gov.in/pdf/Guidelinesforhomequarantine.pdf

Lockdown has two overlapping effects on disease, and modelling suggests that distinguishing between them is important for understanding the situation in India. First, lockdown slows the transmission of the virus by enforcing physical distancing. Second, it slows the geographical spread of disease – the localisation discussed above. Neither effect is absolute, of course.

Lockdown cannot completely stop the virus, but it will slow it down, given, the country has a proper plan of action and has provided the people with all the necessities. Where it has it's drawbacks is that it can affect small scale business and daily wage workers as they go out of work. So it becomes the governments responsibility to provide them with alternatives.

values: Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces such as tables, doorknobs, light switches, counter tops, handles, desks, phones, keyboards, toilets, faucets, and sinks. If surfaces are dirty, clean them using detergent or soap and water prior to disinfection. To disinfect, most common household disinfectants will work.
Community spread means people have been infected with the virus in an area, including some who are not sure how or where they became infected.
Once "community spread" is reached in a location, you will see a rapid rise in the number of cases on a daily basis. This means that the Covid 19 curve is on a rise now.

values.text: Masks should be used as part of a comprehensive strategy of measures to suppress transmission and save lives; the use of a mask alone is not sufficient to provide an adequate level of protection against COVID-19. You should also maintain a minimum physical distance of at least 1 metre from others, frequently clean your hands and avoid touching your face and mask.

Medical masks can protect people wearing the mask from getting infected, as well as can prevent those who have symptoms from spreading them. It is recommended that the following groups use medical masks : 
(1) Health workers
(2) Anyone with symptoms suggestive of COVID-19, including people with mild symptoms 
(3) People caring for suspect or confirmed cases of COVID-19 outside of health facilities

values: Farewell!
Take Care
See ya, Stay Safe
Stay Home, Stay Safe!
Have a great day!
Farewell! I'm always here if you need something else.
I'll be here if you need anything else!
Have a pleasant day!
See ya!
Bye bye, You can always come back if you need anything else.
I'm always here to help you out!

You can encourage your child to help stop the spread of COVID-19 by teaching them to clean hands often using soap and water or alcohol-based hand sanitizer and avoid people who are sick (coughing and sneezing).

Clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces daily in household common areas (e.g. tables, hard-backed chairs, doorknobs, light switches, remotes, handles, desks, toilets, sinks) Launder items including washable plush toys as appropriate in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.
If possible, launder items using the warmest appropriate water setting for the items and dry items completely. Dirty laundry from an ill person can be washed with other people’s items.
You can find additional information on this at https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/advice-for-public where certain guidelines and precautionary measures are provided.

To keep your employees safe, you should: - Consider options to increase physical space between employees and customers such as opening a drive- through, erecting partitions, and marking floors to guide spacing at least six feet apart. - Use hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.

generic.title: Have these in your Covid-19 kit to prevent the virus:

values.text: Employees can be affected if they come in close contact with someone who is affected. It is advised to stay in quarantine for 14 days if you've had travel history or if you think you might have come in contact with a carrier.
Need more information on this?
I'm sorry if I upset you. I'm always trying to improve and get better.
Sorry if I couldn't help. I'm still learning and improving!

values: Practice everyday preventive actions to help reduce your risk of getting sick and remind everyone in your home to do the same. These actions are especially important for older adults and people who have severe chronic medical conditions: Avoid close contact with people who are sick. Cover your coughs and sneezes with a tissue and throw the tissue in the trash. Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing; going to the bathroom; and before eating or preparing food. If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Always wash hands with soap and water if hands are visibly dirty. Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces and objects (e.g., tables, countertops, light switches, doorknobs, and cabinet handles).

Employers should not require sick employees to provide a COVID-19 test result or a healthcare provider’s note to validate their illness, qualify for sick leave, or to return to work. Healthcare provider offices and medical facilities may be extremely busy and not able to provide such documentation in a timely manner.

This is an emerging, rapidly evolving situation and CDC will continue to provide updated information as it becomes available. CDC works 24/7 to protect people’s health.  For CDC guidance please visit: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-nCoV/index.html

Due to the pandemic, most of the schools are adapting in-person lessons to online or virtual learning. Make sure you have good internet connections and a computer that can help your child connect virtually.  Help your child establish a reasonable pace for completing the work. You may need to assist your child with turning on devices, reading instructions, and typing answers. If you are a teacher make sure you have given out a proper schedule to the students to avoid confusion during classes.

values.text: The first human cases of COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus causing COVID-19, subsequently named SARS-CoV-2 were first reported by officials in Wuhan City, China, in December 2019.

Some of the earliest known cases had a link to a wholesale food market in Wuhan, where the patients were either stall owners, market employees, or regular visitors to this market. Environmental samples taken from this market in December 2019 tested positive for SARS-CoV-2, further suggesting that the market in Wuhan City was the source of this outbreak or played a role in the initial amplification of the outbreak.

SARS-CoV-2 was identified in early January and its genetic sequence shared publicly on 11-12 January. The full genetic sequence of SARS-CoV-2 from the early human cases in China and all over the world since then show that SARS-CoV-2 has an ecological origin in bat populations.
Thank you! I'm always trying to learn and get better!
Thank you. I love learning new things so I can help you with all your queries.
Thanks!

With confirmed COVID-19 cases worldwide surpassing 9 million and continuing to grow, scientists are pushing forward with efforts to develop vaccines and treatments to slow the pandemic and lessen the disease’s damage.

As of May 8, two medicationsTrusted Source had received emergency use authorization (EUA) from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA): the antiviral remdesivir and a drug used to sedate people on a ventilator. The FDA issued an EUA in March for the antimalaria drugs chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, but later revoked itTrusted Source after studies showed that they’re unlikely to be effective in treating COVID-19.
Always happy to help!
No problem.
Anytime!

values: Outbreaks can be stressful for adults and children. Talk with your children about the outbreak, try to stay calm, and reassure them that they are safe. If appropriate, explain to them that most illness from COVID-19 seems to be mild. Children respond differently to stressful situations than adults.

Most people who get Covid-19 will be able to recover at home. Keep in mind the following : Stay home when you are sick, except to get medical care. If you develop emergency warning signs for Covid-19 get medical attention immediately.

Emergency warning signs include: Trouble breathing, Persistent pain or pressure in the chest, New confusion or inability to arouse, Bluish lips or face.  This list is not all inclusive. Please consult your medical provider for any other symptoms that are severe or concerning.

Use a separate room and bathroom for sick household members (if possible). Clean hands regularly by hand washing with soap and water or using an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol. Provide your sick household member with clean disposable face masks to wear at home, if available, to help prevent spreading COVID-19 to others. Clean the sick room and bathroom , as needed, to avoid unnecessary contact with the sick person. Avoid sharing personal items like utensils, food, and drinks.
If you want more help regarding home quarantine, you can see the following guidelines provided by the World Health Organisation (WHO) : https://www.mohfw.gov.in/pdf/Guidelinesforhomequarantine.pdf

Based on available evidence, children do not appear to be at higher risk for COVID-19 than adults. While some children and infants have been sick with COVID-19, adults make up most of the known cases to date. You can learn more about who is most at risk for health problems if they have COVID-19 infection. Do you want to know who are at high risk?

values.text: In order to avoid Covid spread, certain guidelines have been set for workplace. Employers should - Provide tissues and no-touch disposal receptacles. - Provide soap and water in the workplace. - Place hand sanitizer in multiple locations to encourage good hand hygiene practices. - Place posters that encourage staying home when sick, the importance of hand hygiene, and coughing and sneezing etiquette at the entrance to your workplace and in other workplace areas where employees are likely to see them. - Discourage handshaking.

For further information regarding this, these are the guidelines been set by the World Health Organisation (WHO) : https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/getting-workplace-ready-for-covid-19.pdf?ua=1

values: Current evidence suggests that COVID-19 spreads between people through direct, indirect (through contaminated objects or surfaces), or close contact with infected people via mouth and nose secretions. These include saliva, respiratory secretions or secretion droplets. These are released from the mouth or nose when an infected person coughs, sneezes or speaks.
People who are in close contact (within 1 metre) with an infected person can catch COVID-19 when those infectious droplets get into their mouth, nose or eyes.
In order to prevent the virus from spreading, follow all the CDC guidelines if you go out. Wear a face mask if necessary and avoid touching anything when outside.

generic.title: Check out these measures given by the World Health Organisation :

values.text: As pregnant women are at a high risk it is advised that you do not skip your prenatal care appointments and limit your interactions with other people as much as possible. If you do interact, take precautions. Make sure that you have at least a 30-day supply of your medicines. It is important you talk to your healthcare provider about how to stay healthy and take care of yourself during the COVID-19 pandemic. In case you do not have one, contact your nearest community health or health department. Seek care immediately in terms of any medical emergency.
You may feel increased stress during this pandemic. Fear and anxiety can be overwhelming and cause strong emotions. Learn about stress and coping.
You can refer to these guidelines provided by CDC : https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/need-extra-precautions/pregnancy-breastfeeding.html

values.text: As Covid-19 spreads from person-to-person, the one way you can protect yourself is by social distancing; It will also slow down the outbreak in order to reduce the chance of infection among high-risk populations and to reduce the burden on health care systems and workers
It is advised to maintain a distance of 6 feet, avoiding public places as much as possible.
You should also maintain good hygiene and disinfect things you come in direct contact with on a daily basis.

values: It is advised to wear face masks while you take your child to a place that could see a large crowd. However, face masks haven't been proven to prevent the virus from spreading. So it is advised to take precautions and follow the Covid-19 guidelines.

Depending on the situation, public health officials may recommend community actions to reduce exposures to COVID-19, such as school dismissals. Read or watch local media sources that report school dismissals or and watch for communication from your child’s school. If schools are dismissed temporarily, discourage students and staff from gathering or socializing anywhere, like at a friend’s house, a favorite restaurant, or the local shopping mall.

For recommendations and guidance on persons under investigation; infection control, including personal protective equipment guidance; home care and isolation; and case investigation, ask this chatbot about Information for Healthcare Professionals . For information on specimen collection and shipment, ask this chatbot about Information for Laboratories. For information for public health professional on COVID-19, ask this chatbot about Information for Public Health Professionals.

Social Distancing Strategies that businesses could use include: - Allowing flexible worksites (such as telework) - Allowing flexible work hours (such as staggered shifts) - Increasing physical space between employees at the worksite - Increasing physical space between employees and customers (such as a drive-through and partitions) - Implementing flexible meeting and travel options (such as postponing non-essential meetings or events) - Downsizing operations - Delivering services remotely (e.g., phone, video, or web) - Delivering products through curbside pick-up or delivery

Create a household plan of action to help protect your health and the health of those you care about in the event of an outbreak of Covid-19 in your community: Talk with the people who need to be included in your plan, and discuss what to do if a Covid-19 outbreak occurs in your community Plan ways to care for those who might be at greater risk for serious complications, particularly older adults and those with severe chronic medical conditions like heart, lung or kidney disease. Make sure they have access to several weeks of medications and supplies in case you need to stay home for prolonged periods of time. Get to know your neighbours and find out if your neighbourhood has a website or social media page to stay connected. Create a list of local organisations that you and your household can contact in the event you need access to information, healthcare services, support, and resources. Create an emergency contact list of family, friends, neighbours, carpool drivers, health care providers, teachers, employers, the local public health department, and other community resources.

The more people interact, the closer in distance the interaction is (less than 6 feet), and the longer the interaction lasts, the higher the risk of spreading COVID-19. If you want to attend a funeral, it is advised you take the necessary precautions to avoid the spreading of the virus.  If you have been tested positive or show symptoms, it's advised you don't go to large gatherings as you could be a carrier of the virus and could spread it further.

values.text: COVID-19 affects different people in different ways. Most infected people will develop mild to moderate illness and recover without hospitalization. The symptoms can range as follows :
Most common symptoms: fever, dry cough, cold and tiredness
Less common symptoms: aches and pains, sore throat, diarrhoea, conjunctivitis, headache, loss of taste or smell, a rash on skin, or discolouration of fingers or toes

Serious symptoms: difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, chest pain or pressure, loss of speech or movement. Seek immediate medical attention if you have serious symptoms. Always call before visiting your doctor or health facility.

values: State and local officials should have developed a list of essential critical infrastructure workers to help state and local officials as they work to protect their communities, while ensuring continuity of functions critical to public health and safety as well as economic and national security.

values.text: Older adults and people of any age who have serious underlying medical conditions may be at higher risk for more serious complications from COVID-19. Based upon available information to date, those most at risk include People 65 years and older, people who live in a nursing home or long-term care facility.

People of any age with the following underlying medical conditions are also at high risk :  Chronic lung disease or asthma, Congestive heart failure or coronary artery disease, Diabetes, Neurological conditions that weaken ability to cough, Weakened immune system, Chemotherapy or radiation for cancer (currently or in recent past), Sickle cell anemia, Chronic kidney disease requiring dialysis, Cirrhosis of the liver, Lack of spleen or a spleen that doesn’t function correctly and Extreme obesity (body mass index [BMI] > 40)
Pregnant woman can also be at a high risk and hence it's important they follow certain guidelines. Do you want more information on Covid-19 and pregnancy?

values: Wear cloth face coverings in public settings where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain, especially in areas of significant community transmission. Employees should continue to follow their routine policies and procedures for PPE (if any) that they would ordinarily use for their job tasks.

values.text: According to WebMD, the World Health Organization, and other healthcare experts, there is no evidence yet that COVID-19 can be transmitted through food. However, it is important to take precautions. These can be :
Before preparing or eating food it is important to always wash your hands with soap and water for 20 seconds for general food safety.

Rinse your vegetables, fruits or eggs under running water When unpacking groceries, refrigerate or freeze meat, poultry, eggs, seafood, and other perishables within 2 hours of purchasing.
Do NOT use disinfectants designed for hard surfaces, such as bleach or ammonia, on food packaged in cardboard or plastic wrap.
For in depth information, these are the guidelines set by CDC that can be followed : https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/food-and-COVID-19.html

Some coronaviruses that infect animals can be spread to humans and then spread between people, but this is rare. The virus that causes COVID-19 spreads mainly from person to person. At this time, there is no evidence that animals play a significant role in spreading the virus that causes COVID-19. Based on the limited information available to date, the risk of animals spreading COVID-19 to people is considered to be low. More studies are needed to understand if and how different animals could be affected by COVID-19.
Do you want more information of the risks to pets?

Some measures to prevent Covid 19 transmission at workplace include - frequent hand-washing or disinfection with alcohol based hand sanitizer, respiratory hygiene such as covering coughs, physical distancing of at least 1 metre or more according to the national recommendations, wearing of masks where distancing is not possible, regular environmental cleaning and disinfection, and limiting unnecessary travel.

Also, clear policies and messages, training, and education for staff and managers to increase awareness of COVID-19 are essential. The management of people with COVID-19 or their contacts is also critical e.g. requiring workers who are unwell or who develop symptoms to stay at home, self isolate and contact a medical professional or the local COVID-19 information line for advice on testing and referral.
Do you need further information on workplace hygiene?

values: In COVID-19, ‘CO’ stands for ‘corona,’ ‘VI’ for ‘virus,’ and ‘D’ for disease. Formerly, this disease was referred to as “2019 novel coronavirus”. The name of this disease was selected following the WHO's best practice for naming of new human infectious diseases.

Hand washing is one of the best ways to protect yourself and your family from getting sick. Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, especially after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing; going to the bathroom; and before eating or preparing food. If soap and water are not readily available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

f you have a fever, cough or other symptoms, you might have COVID-19. Most people have mild illness and are able to recover at home. If you think you may have been exposed to COVID-19, contact your healthcare provider. Keep track of your symptoms. If you have an emergency warning sign (including trouble breathing), get emergency medical care immediately.
Older patients and individuals who have severe underlying medical conditions or are immuno compromised should contact their healthcare provider early, even if their illness is mild.
Do you want me to show you what the Covid-19 symptoms are?

values.text: We are still learning about the virus that causes COVID-19, but it appears that it can spread from people to animals in some situations. A small number of pets worldwide, including cats and dogs, have been reported to be infected with the virus that causes COVID-19, mostly after close contact with people with COVID-19. Infected pets might get sick or they might not have any symptoms. Of the pets that have gotten sick, most only had mild illness and fully recovered. Until we learn more about how this virus affects animals, treat pets as you would other human family members to protect them from a possible infection. Because there is a small risk that people with COVID-19 could spread the virus to animals, CDC recommends that pet owners limit their pet’s interaction with people outside their household.
You can refer to the following CDC guidelines if you have pets at home : https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/pets.html

People are anxious about the unknown and this can be overwhelming. People with pre-exiting mental health conditions may respond more strongly to stressful situations. If you find yourself in this situation, keep appointments with your mental health provider. Also make sure the appointments are virtual.
In a time like this, keep your mental health in check and also make sure you look after your loved ones. Specially the elderly as this time could be a lot more confusing for them.
If you feel depressed, please get professional help. Do not isolate yourself and try fighting this alone.
The Live Laugh Love Foundation : https://thelivelovelaughfoundation.org/index.html
Indian govt. toll free helpline number : 08046110007
National Institute of Mental Health and Neuro-Sciences (NIMHANS) toll free number : 08046110007
Vandrevala Foundation : https://www.vandrevalafoundation.com/

If you are a victim of domestic violence, contact these numbers : Women Helpline ( All India ) -
Women In Distress - 1091
Women Helpline Domestic Abuse - 181
Police - 100
Numbers of each state : https://indianhelpline.com/WOMEN-HELPLINE/
If you are suicidal, get immediate help from these contacts :
iCall : 91-9152987821 ; AASRA : 91-9820466726; State Wise Contacts : https://indianhelpline.com/SUICIDE-HELPLINE/
AASRA : http://aasra.info/
Cooj Mental Health FOundation : https://cooj.co.in/
Sneha : https://snehaindia.org/new/
Parivarthan : https://parivarthan.org/

dialog_nodes.title: Guidance on going in to work

values: Follow the advice of your local health officials. Stay home if you can. Talk to your employer to discuss working from home, taking leave if you or someone in your household gets sick with COVID-19 symptoms , or if your child’s school is dismissed temporarily. Employers should be aware that more employees may need to stay at home to care for sick children or other sick family members than is usual in case of a community outbreak.

Stigma is discrimination against an identifiable group of people, a place, or a nation. Stigma is associated with a lack of knowledge about how COVID-19 spreads, a need to blame someone, fears about disease and death, and gossip that spreads rumours and myths. Stigma hurts everyone by creating more fear or anger towards ordinary people instead of the disease that is causing the problem. It is necessary that every individual educates themselves on how the virus spreads.

values.text: Someone who is actively sick with COVID-19 can spread the illness to others hence it's recommended that these patients be isolated either in the hospital or at home (depending on how sick they are) until they are better and no longer pose a risk of infecting others.
The COVID-19 recovery process, including how quickly you can expect to recover, depends on whether you have a mild, moderate or severe case of the illness.

Current CDC guidance for when it is okay to release someone from isolation is made on a case by case basis and includes meeting all of the following requirements: The patient is free from fever without the use of fever-reducing medications. The patient is no longer showing symptoms, including cough. The patient has tested negative on at least two consecutive respiratory specimens collected at least 24 hours apart.

Even after you've recovered, you should consider wearing a cloth face covering while out in public or at home if you share it with other people. You should also disinfect commonly touched surfaces and constantly wash your hands with soap and water, or sanitize them with a sanitizer.

dialog_nodes.title: What symptoms are shown in Children?

values: The symptoms of COVID-19 are similar in children and adults. However, children with confirmed COVID-19 have generally presented with mild symptoms. Reported symptoms in children include cold-like symptoms, such as fever, runny nose, and cough. Vomiting and diarrhea have also been reported. Some children may be at higher risk for severe illness, for example, children with underlying medical conditions and special healthcare needs. There is much more to be learned about how the disease impacts children, but it is always better to take precautions specially for the ones that have other medical conditions.

A negative result means that the virus that causes Covid-19 was not found in the person’s sample. In the early stages of infection, it is possible the virus will not be detected. For Covid-19, a negative test result for a sample collected while a person has symptoms likely means that the Covid-19 virus is not causing their current illness.

values.text: First clean dirty surfaces with soap and water. Second, disinfect surfaces using a cleaner appropriate for the surface. If machinery or equipment are thought to be contaminated and cannot be cleaned, they can be isolated.
Do you want more information workplace precautions?

values: It is not yet known whether weather and temperature impact the spread of COVID-19. Some other viruses, like the common cold and flu, spread more during cold weather months but that does not mean it is impossible to become sick with these viruses during other months. At this time, it is not known whether the spread of COVID-19 will decrease when weather becomes warmer. There is much more to learn about the transmissibility, severity, and other features associated with COVID-19 and investigations are ongoing.

If you show any  symptoms similar to that of Covid 19, or have come in contact with someone who has been tested positive, it is advised to get yourself tested.
If your symptoms are mild, you can self quarantine yourself at home. Which means you'd have to stay at home for minimum 14 days or until your symptoms are completely gone.
Do you need some more information on quarantine?

values: The key to slowing the spread of Covid-19 is to limit social interactions as much as possible. Parents should minimise play dates, and if held, parents should keep the groups small. Advise older children to hang out in a small group and to meet up outside rather than inside. It’s easier to keep and maintain space between others in outdoor settings, like parks. If you have small meetups, consider hanging out with another family or friend who is also taking extra measures to put distance between themselves and others (i.e. social distancing). Make sure children practice everyday preventive behaviours , such as cleaning and then disinfecting frequently touched surfaces. Even though children do not fall in the category of 'high risk', they can still pass this virus onto others who may be at higher risk, including older adults and people who have serious chronic medical conditions

There is still a lot that is unknown about the newly emerged COVID-19 and how it spreads. Two other coronaviruses have emerged previously to cause severe illness in people (MERS-CoV and SARS-CoV). The virus that causes COVID-19 is more genetically related to SARS-CoV than MERS-CoV, but both are betacoronaviruses with their origins in bats. While we don’t know for sure that this virus will behave the same way as SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, we can use the information gained from both of these earlier coronaviruses to guide us. In general, because of poor survivability of these coronaviruses on surfaces, there is likely very low risk of spread from products or packaging that are shipped over a period of days or weeks at ambient temperatures. Coronaviruses are generally thought to be spread most often by respiratory droplets.
